description:
A calm village residing in the mountains comes under attack from a demon-possessed boar one day.

Ashitaka, a young man and prince of the tribe, engages the creature in an attempt to save his village. During the battle, the boar bites him on the arm, leaving it blackened and cursed. Following his village's traditions, Ashitaka is exiled and becomes a wanderer, looking for a solution to the curse before it engulfs him.

Iron Town is a fortress under the leadership of Lady Eboshi. Through the clearing of the surrounding forests, Iron Town produces large amounts of Ironsand, used for gunpowder and other machinery. However, because of the forests destruction, nearby animal clans seek revenge led by a human girl of the Wolf clan called San.

When Ashitaka comes to Iron Town, he discovers the area consumed in battle. Horrified, he attempts to create peace and befriend the Wolf Clan. However, after the forest's eradication and the ongoing war between Human and Beast, will the Spirit of the Forest be forgiving and accept Ashitaka's request to expel his curse?

[Written by MAL Rewrite]

tags.name: Environmental
tags.description: Concern with the state of the natural world and how humans interact with it.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Mythology
tags.description: Prominently features mythological elements, especially those from religious or cultural tradition.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Eco-Horror
tags.description: Utilizes a horrifying depiction of ecology to explore man and its relationship with nature.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Gods
tags.description: Prominently features a character of divine or religious nature.

tags.name: Wilderness
tags.description: Predominantly features a location with little to no human activity, such as a deserted island, a jungle, or a snowy mountain range.

tags.name: Demons
tags.description: Prominently features malevolent otherworldly creatures.

tags.name: Rural
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the countryside.

tags.name: Youkai
tags.description: Prominently features supernatural creatures from Japanese folklore.

tags.name: Revenge
tags.description: Prominently features a character who aims to exact punishment in a resentful or vindictive manner.

tags.name: Female Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is female.

tags.name: Curses
tags.description: Features a character, object or area that has been cursed, usually by a malevolent supernatural force.

tags.name: Historical
tags.description: Partly or completely set during a real period of world history.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Male Protagonist
tags.description: Main character is male.

tags.name: Guns
tags.description: Prominently features the use of guns in combat.

tags.name: Disability
tags.description: A work that features one or more characters with a physical, mental, cognitive, or developmental condition that impairs, interferes with, or limits the person's ability to engage in certain tasks or actions.

tags.name: Travel
tags.description: Centers around character(s) moving between places a significant distance apart.

tags.name: Urban Fantasy
tags.description: Set in a world similar to the real world, but with the existence of magic or other supernatural elements.

tags.name: Samurai
tags.description: Prominently features warriors of medieval Japanese nobility bound by a code of honor.

tags.name: Archery
tags.description: Centers around the sport of archery, or prominently features the use of archery in combat.

tags.name: Tomboy
tags.description: Features a girl who exhibits characteristics or behaviors considered in many cultures to be typical of boys.

tags.name: Outdoor Activities
tags.description: Centers around hiking, camping or other outdoor activities.

tags.name: Body Horror
tags.description: Features characters who undergo horrific transformations or disfigurement, often to their own detriment.

tags.name: Gore
tags.description: Prominently features graphic bloodshed and violence.

tags.name: Slavery
tags.description: Prominently features slaves, slavery, or slave trade.

tags.name: Swordplay
tags.description: Prominently features the use of swords in combat.

tags.name: Kaiju
tags.description: Prominently features giant monsters.

tags.name: Indigenous Cultures
tags.description: Prominently features real-life indigenous cultures.

name.native: 木霊, 木魂, or 木魅

node.description:
__Residency:__ Tokorozawa City, Saitama Prefecture, Japan
__Graduated:__ Gakushuin University (Department of Economics)

__Introduction:__
Hayao Miyazaki is a Japanese animator, director, script/screenwriter, author, mangaka and co-founder of Studio Ghibli. He is the second of four brothers, and was born in the town of Akebono-cho, part of Tokyo's Bunkyou Ward. He is best known for his international fame as a masterful storyteller and as a maker of astonishing animated feature films, and he is widely regarded as one of the most accomplished filmmakers in the history of animation.

Miyazaki's works are characterized by the recurrence of themes such as humanity's relationship with nature and technology, the wholesomeness of natural and traditional patterns of living, the importance of art and craftsmanship, and the difficulty of maintaining a pacifist ethic in a violent world. The protagonists of his films are often strong girls or young women, and several of his films present morally ambiguous antagonists with redeeming qualities. Miyazaki's works have been highly praised and awarded; he was named a Person of Cultural Merit for outstanding cultural contributions in November 2012, and received the Academy Honorary Award for his impact on animation and cinema in November 2014, as well as having won two Oscars for Best Animated Feature, the only instances in which a non-English-language film has won the award. Miyazaki has frequently been cited as an inspiration for numerous animators, directors, and writers.

__Biography:__
Miyazaki expressed interest in manga and animation from an early age, which led to him eventually joining [Toei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/18/Toei-Animation) in 1963. During his early years at Toei Animation he worked as an in-between artist and later collaborated with the director [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/Isao-Takahata). Some notable films Miyazaki contributed to at Toei include [Doggie March](https://anilist.co/anime/9228/Wan-Wan-Chuushingura/) and [Gulliver's Travels Beyond the Moon](https://anilist.co/anime/2833/Gullivers-Travels-Beyond-the-Moon/). He provided key animation in other films at Toei, such as the Puss in Boots and Animal Treasure Island, before moving to animation studio A-Pro in 1971, where he would co-direct the movie Lupin the Third Part I alongside Isao Takahata. After moving to Zuiyou Eizou (later dubbed [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/Nippon-Animation)) in 1973, Miyazaki worked as an animator on World Masterpiece Theater, and directed the television series [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/Future-Boy-Conan/). He joined [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/Telecom-Animation-Film)/Tokyo Movie Shinsa in 1979 to direct his first feature films, [The Castle of Cagliostro](https://anilist.co/anime/1430/Lupin-The-3rd-The-Castle-of-Cagliostro/) in 1979 and [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/Nausica-of-the-Valley-of-the-Wind/) in 1984, as well as the television series [Sherlock Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/1972/Sherlock-Hound/).

Miyazaki co-founded [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/Studio-Ghibli) in 1985. He would go on to direct numerous of films with Ghibli, including [Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/Castle-in-the-Sky/) (1986), [My Neighbor Totoro](https://anilist.co/anime/523/My-Neighbor-Totoro/) (1988), [Kiki's Delivery Service](https://anilist.co/anime/512/Kikis-Delivery-Service/) (1989), and [Porco Rosso](https://anilist.co/anime/416/Porco-Rosso/) (1992). The films they made were met with critical and commercial success in Japan. His film [Princess Mononoke](https://anilist.co/anime/164/Princess-Mononoke/) was the first animated film to ever win the Japan Academy Prize for Picture of the Year, and it briefly became the highest-grossing film in Japan following its release in 1997, and its distribution to the Western world greatly increased Studio Ghibli's popularity and influence outside of Japan. His 2001 film [Spirited Away](https://anilist.co/anime/199/Spirited-Away/) became the highest-grossing film in Japanese history, winning the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature at the 75th Academy Awards and is frequently ranked among the greatest films of the 2000s. Miyazaki's later films, [Howl's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/Howls-Moving-Castle/) (2004), [Ponyo](https://anilist.co/anime/2890/Ponyo/) (2008), and [The Wind Rises](https://anilist.co/anime/16662/The-Wind-Rises/) (2013) also enjoyed critical and commercial success.

Following the release of The Wind Rises, Miyazaki announced his retirement from feature films, though he returned again in 2016 to work on a new feature film, [The Boy and The Heron](https://anilist.co/anime/109979/The-Boy-and-the-Heron/) (2023). The film received critical acclaim, becoming the first non-English-language film to win the Golden Globe for Best Animated Feature Film, and the second non-English-language film, after Spirited Away, to win the Oscar for Best Animated Feature at the 96th Academy Awards. According to Studio Ghibli vice-president [Junichi Nishioka](https://anilist.co/staff/212700/Junichi-Nishioka) and long-time colleague, [Toshio Suzuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101638/Toshio-Suzuki), Miyazaki is reportedly working on another feature film, contrary to rumours that The Boy and the Heron would be his last.

__Graduated:__ Gakushuin University (Department of Economics)

Following the release of The Wind Rises, Miyazaki announced his retirement from feature films, though he returned again in 2016 to work on a new feature film, [The Boy and The Heron](https://anilist.co/anime/109979/The-Boy-and-the-Heron/) (2023). __Alma mater:__ Tokyo Designer Gakuin College (Animation Department)

Freelance animator and anime director. Married to Naoko Shiraishi, ex-Shaft/Gainax producer and founder of the animation studio Millepensee. He has a [weekly column](http://animestyle.jp/column/battari/) at Anime Style.

[Website](http://joehisaishi.com/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCxyzciBLt1Hyw06dlqwAIkw) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/official_joeh) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/joehisaishi.official/)

Mamoru Fujisawa, known professionally as Joe Hisaishi, is a Japanese composer and musical director known for over 100 film scores and solo albums dating back to 1981. He has been associated with filmmaker [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) since 1984, having composed scores for all but one of his films. Hisaishi is also widely known for his piano scores.

While possessing a stylistically distinct sound, Hisaishi's music has been known to explore and incorporate different genres, including minimalist, experimental electronic, European classical, and Japanese classical. Lesser known are the other musical roles he plays; he is also a typesetter, author, arranger, and conductor. Hisaishi was a student of composer [Takeo Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/106839/).

Hisaishi started learning violin in the Violin School Suzuki Shinichi at the age of four, he found his passion in music. At the same age, he also began watching 300 movies a year with his father, which influenced his career. Realizing his love, he attended the Kunitachi College of Music in 1969 to major in music composition. Hisaishi collaborated with minimalist artists as a typesetter, furthering his experience in the musical world.

He enjoyed his first success of the business in 1974 when he composed music for the anime series called [Gyatoruzu](https://anilist.co/anime/8763/). This and other early works were created under his given name. He presented his first public performance in the mid '70s, spreading his name around his community.

In 1983, Hisaishi was recommended to create an image album for [Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind](https://anilist.co/anime/572/). Hisaishi and the director of the animated film, Hayao Miyazaki, became great friends and would work together on many future projects. In 1985, he founded his own recording studio—the wonder station. Their collaboration has invited comparisons to the collaborations of Steven Spielberg and John Williams. This big break led to Hisaishi's overwhelming success as a composer of film scores. In 1986, [Laputa: Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/) would be the first feature to appear under the [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) banner, and its gentle, faintly melancholic tone would become a familiar trademark of much of the studio's later output. As Hisaishi strengthened his reputation as one of the budding anime industry's top musical contributors, his compositions would proceed to become some of the very hallmarks of early anime in the '80s and '90s.

Hisaishi formulated an alias inspired by Quincy Jones, an African-American musician and producer. Re-transcribed in Japanese, "Quincy Jones" became "Joe Hisaishi". ("Quincy", pronounced "Kuinshī” in Japanese, can be written using the same kanji in "Hisaishi"; "Joe" comes from "Jones".)

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Website](http://joehisaishi.com/) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCxyzciBLt1Hyw06dlqwAIkw) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/official_joeh) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/joehisaishi.official/)

Their collaboration has invited comparisons to the collaborations of Steven Spielberg and John Williams. This big break led to Hisaishi's overwhelming success as a composer of film scores. In 1986, [Laputa: Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/) would be the first feature to appear under the [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) banner, and its gentle, faintly melancholic tone would become a familiar trademark of much of the studio's later output. As Hisaishi strengthened his reputation as one of the budding anime industry's top musical contributors, his compositions would proceed to become some of the very hallmarks of early anime in the '80s and '90s.

Hisaishi formulated an alias inspired by Quincy Jones, an African-American musician and producer. Re-transcribed in Japanese, "Quincy Jones" became "Joe Hisaishi". ("Quincy", pronounced "Kuinshī” in Japanese, can be written using the same kanji in "Hisaishi"; "Joe" comes from "Jones".)

(Source: Wikipedia)

English author of science fiction, fantasy short stories,  novels, graphic novels, comics, and films. His notable works include The Sandman comic series, Stardust, and American Gods.  He adapted Princess Mononoke into English.

Jack Fletcher is a voice actor, casting director, and voice director. He has done voice casting and direction for many high-profile anime and video game projects. In addition, he is a well known and respected theatre director and teacher, having spent a number of years teaching and directing at the American Conservatory theatre in San Francisco, as well as at many other theatres.  

(Source: Wikipedia)

Toshio Suzuki  is a film producer of anime and a long-time colleague of [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), as well as the former president of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/). Suzuki is renowned as one of Japan's most successful producers after the enormous national box office success of many Ghibli films.

He was instrumental in getting the [Nausicaä](https://anilist.co/anime/572/) anime made and helped establish Studio Ghibli shortly after the film's release. Miyazaki has stated, "If it were not for Mr. Suzuki, there wouldn't have been Studio Ghibli." Ghibli co-founder [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), has acknowledged the pivotal role of Suzuki in bringing the Nausicaä manga series into the world and used nearly identical words as Miyazaki to acknowledge Suzuki’s essential role in the creation of Studio Ghibli. Takahata also credits Suzuki for his steadfast support of Miyazaki and has cited Suzuki’s responsibility for making his friendship with Miyazaki endure.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Yoshifumi Kondou was a Japanese animator who worked for [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) in his last years, and was most known for directing the film [Whisper of the Heart](https://anilist.co/anime/585/). He was expected to become one of the top directors at Studio Ghibli, alongside [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/) and [Isao Takahata](https://anilist.co/staff/100579/), and to become their eventual successor.

Kondou entered Niigata Prefectural Muramatsu High School in April, 1965, where he was a member of the art club. In the school, one of his seniors was the future manga artist [Kimio Yanagisawa](https://anilist.co/staff/100609/). In April, 1968, he moved to Tokyo after graduating from high school, where he entered Tokyo Design College's animation department. In October, 1968, he began working at [Shin-Ei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/247/), then A Production. There he took part in the production of shows like [Kyojin no Hoshi](https://anilist.co/anime/5834/) and [Lupin III](https://anilist.co/anime/1412/). In 1978, Kondou moved to [Nippon Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/22/), where he worked on shows such as [Future Boy Conan](https://anilist.co/anime/302/) and [Anne of Green Gables](https://anilist.co/anime/283/), making his proper character designing debut in the latter.

In December 1980, Kondou moved to [Telecom Animation Film](https://anilist.co/studio/94/), where he served as the character designer for [Sherlock Hound](https://anilist.co/anime/1972/). Kondou resigned from his position at Telecom in March of 1985, and was hospitalized from June through August for a type of pneumonia. He became a contract worker for Nippon Animation afterwards and moved to Studio Ghibli in January, 1987.

In 1995, he made his directorial debut with the renown Studio Ghibli film, Whisper of the Heart.

Kondou suddenly passed away from an aortic dissection on January 21, 1998, which according to doctors had been brought on by overwork. Kondou’s death is also believed to be the reason for Miyazaki’s initial announcement of retirement.

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/近藤勝也)

Famous for his character designs on numerous of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s films, which are considered the epitome of the Ghibli style.

After graduating from high school, he began working for [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/) at their Studio Annapuru. Under the direction of [Shinji Ootsuka](https://anilist.co/staff/124192/), Kondou worked as a key animator of the TV anime series Cat's Eye. He then worked as a free agent on such shows as [The Mighty Orbots](https://anilist.co/anime/8130/), Rainbow Brite and Disney's Adventures of the Gummi Bears. His first work with Studio Ghibli was as a key animator on [Castle in the Sky](https://anilist.co/anime/513/). After working on the Gainax film [The Wings of Honneamise](https://anilist.co/anime/1034/) and multiple OVAs around late '80s, Kondou began to be known for the high quality of his work.

He has also collaborated collaborated with Kenichi Sakemi on a manga retelling of the Joan of Arc story, as well as doing the character designs for the Jade Cocoon video game series.

(Source: Wikipedia)

Kousaka began his career in 1979 at Oh! Production, debuting as an in-betweener on [Moero Arthur: Hakuba no Ouji](https://anilist.co/anime/4614/), and as a key animator on [Minami no Niji no Lucy](https://anilist.co/anime/2573/) in 1982, and got instructed by animators like [Toshitsugu Saida](https://anilist.co/staff/186591/) and [Kouichi Murata](https://anilist.co/staff/191548/).

Before having gone freelance in 1986, he had partaken in [Nausicaä](https://anilist.co/anime/572/) as an animator, working alongide famed director [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), whose work he himself is an admitted fan. He has since worked on numerous of Miyazaki's and [Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/)'s films as both an animator and an animation director.

In 2003, he directed the cycling anime film, [Nasu: Summer in Andalusia](https://anilist.co/anime/1209/), set on the Vuelta a España road bicycle race, adapted from [Iou Kuroda](https://anilist.co/staff/97910/)'s manga [Nasu](https://anilist.co/manga/31245/), which Miyazaki, a fan of cycling, had recommended to Kousaka. The film soon went on to become the first Japanese anime film ever to be selected for the Cannes Film Festival.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/gallo44_yoshida)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%B8%AD%E5%B1%B1%E5%A4%A7%E8%BC%94_(%E3%82%A2%E3%83%BC%E3%83%86%E3%82%A3%E3%82%B9%E3%83%88%29)

Daisuke Nakayama is a director, animator and character designer.
Handles special effects.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1179422512028864512)

Currently he is a member of [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/), having formerly been a part of [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) for over 18 years from 1996 to 2015. While he was still at Ghibli, he made his directorial debut as a 37-year-old with [The Secret World of Arrietty](https://anilist.co/anime/7711/), and became the youngest director of a theatrical feature produced by the studio. [Tomomi Mochizuki](https://anilist.co/staff/101821/), a director of a 1993 TV special, [Ocean Waves](https://anilist.co/anime/743/), is the youngest director of a Ghibli film at 34.

In 2015, Yonebayashi left with producer [Yoshiaki Nishimura](https://anilist.co/staff/121954/) and established Studio Ponoc. His first film at the new studio was [Mary and the Witch's Flower](https://anilist.co/anime/97981/).

Nominated for the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature in 2015 for his second film, [When Marnie Was There](https://anilist.co/anime/20555/).

__Birthplace:__ Nemuro, Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan

Masayoshi Ookawa is a music producer and recording engineer. After graduation from university, he worked for Aoi Studio as a music engineer. In July 2003, he founded the music production company Bic River situated in Minato, Tokyo, and became its representative director.

(Source: Anidb)

A highly prolific and an extremely influential animator.

Know for his experimentation with the timing of keyframes, his dynamic poses, and his peculiar effects Kanada pioneered a number of techniques and concepts that permeated and shaped the Japanese animation industry, influencing not only his peers but also the generations to come.

Kanada's ability and his tendency to be very personal with his drawings, even to the point of ignoring storyboards if the situation required, popularized in the industry the concept of letting the individual animator's talents shine instead of being uniformed into anonymity. This precept is still respected today and it's one of the reasons Japanese animation is so distinctly unique. His career is also a testament to his ethos that expressive and vibrant animation is not achieved simply through increasing the number of frames but through playing with movement, poses and timing.

In the early '00s, Kanada became an employee at Square Enix.

Notable Square Enix titles in which he was credited:

~!
- 2002, Final Fantasy XI (Motion Capture, Animation Director)
- 2005, Musashiden II: Blade Master (Storyboard)
- 2006, Dawn of Mana (Facial Setting)
- 2007, Final Fantasy 4 DS Version (Storyboard)
- 2009, Final Fantasy XIII (Storyboard Director) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2011, Final Fantasy XIII-2 (Storyboard) - *Posthumous credit.*
- 2012, Dragon Quest X (Storyboard)  - *Posthumous credit.* !~
Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/). Freelance since 2003.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenichi_0623) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/小西賢一)

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

Noted for his work as a character designer on tiles such as [Tokyo Godfathers](https://anilist.co/anime/759/), [Bokurano](https://anilist.co/anime/1690/) and [Children of the Sea](https://anilist.co/anime/103221/).
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/河口俊夫)

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/伊藤道廣)

Founder and representative director of Sound Ring.
Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/). Close friends with [Kenichi Yoshida](https://anilist.co/staff/103498/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/sakouyukie) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BD%90%E5%85%89%E5%B9%B8%E6%81%B5)

Yukie Sakou is an animator and character designer.
